title: A program that manipulates text material and allows the user to make corrections, additions, deletions, and other changes
Endless loop or jump-to-self instruction. An instruction that transfers control to itself, thus executing indefinitely (or until a hardware signal interrupts it
Placing values in storage areas not previously in use, initializing memory or storage

note: Common highlevel languages include BASIC, COBOL, FORTRAN, and Pascal.
title: Number system with base 16. The digits are the decimal numbers through 9, followed by the letters A through F. Hex cqde. See Object code. High-level language. A programming language that is aimed toward the solution of problems, rather than being designed for convenient conversion into computer instructions. Acompiler or interpreter translates a program written in a high-level language into a form that the computer can execute
Instruction cycle. The process of fetching, decoding, and executing an instruction
Instruction execution time. The time required to fetch, decode, and execute an instruction
A signal that temporarily suspends the computer's normal sequence of operations and transfers control to a special routine
See Input/output control block
A computer language in which each statement is translated directly into a single machine language instruction
A computer that has a microprocessor as its central processing unit
Page 0. In 6502 terminology, the lowest 256 addresses in memory
An interface between a CPU and input or output devices that handle data in parallel (more than one bit at a time

note: flag (F) register, status register, and status word.
title: A register that defines the current state of a computer,, often containing various bits indicating internal conditions. Other names for this register include condition code register
A device that can handle a variety of timing tasks, including the generation of delays, under program control
A memory that can be read but not altered in normal operation

note: It has been partially superseded by RS-449.
title: A standard interface for the transmission of serial digital data, sponsored by the Electronic Industries Association of
SDLC (Synchronous Data Link Control). The successor protocol to BSC for IBM computers and terminals
Halts execution and preserves the status of the task until some future time
A character that is used only to synchronize the transmitter and the receiver
A self-contained program that can serve as part of an overall system under the control of a supervisor
A data item that has no function other than to signify the end of an array
A debugging aid that provides information about a program while the program is being executed. The trace usually prints all or some of the intermediate results
See Versatile Interface Adapter
